item.title: Greenberg pays $15m in SEC settlement
item.description: Hank Greenberg, the former chairman of American International Group, agreed to pay $15m to settle the US Securities and Exchange Commission’s investigation into his role in accounting fraud at the company from 2000 to 2005

item.title: Senate confirms Supreme Court nominee
item.description: The US Senate voted to confirm Sonia Sotomayor as a Supreme Court judge , handing President Barack Obama a victory his administration had sought for weeks

item.title: The liquidity pipes remain clogged
item.description: Banks seem unwilling to use spare liquidity to engage in activity that regulators or shareholders might deem risky, writes Gillian Tett

item.title: Success predicted for ‘clunkers’ extension
item.description: Congressional aides predicted support for a $2bn extension to the ‘cash for clunkers’ scheme, as the US Senate voted to confirm Sonia Sotomayor’s nomination to the Supreme Court in a scramble to finish business before breaking for its summer recess

item.title: Merkel moves on failing German banks
item.description: Angela Merkel would give the German banking supervisor unprecedented powers over struggling banks, including the capacity to dismiss executives, if re-elected chancellor next month, according to legislation being drafted by her economics minister

item.title: M Stanley to pay $950m for Tarp warrants
item.description: Morgan Stanley is to pay $950m to sever yet another link to the US government’s bail-out plan, buying back warrants it gave the authorities as part of a $10bn capital injection at the height of the crisis last year

item.title: Investor demand fuels rebound in ETFs
item.description: Assets invested globally in exchange traded funds have reached a record high of $862bn on the back of the partial recovery in stock markets and the continuing strong demand for passive investment

item.title: Concerted cyber-attack takes down Twitter
item.description: What might have been no more than a teenage prank knocked Twitter, the fast-growing internet communications service, offline for more than two hours

item.title: Wall Street falls on economic jitters
item.description: For the first time this week the S&P 500 closed below the 1,000-point threshold, as healthcare, retail, energy and telecoms stocks weighed on sentiment ahead of today’s US monthly jobs report
